YES and NO
PORTRAIT OF A PROFESSOR
There is a man at Hopkins, and he is wondrous wise;
He first removes his spectacles and rubs at both his eyes;
And when he finds his eyes are rubbed, and lessened of their pain,
He then picks up his spectacles, and puts them on again.
There is a man at Hopkins who finds it difficult
To discover on his list of.words any one of sense occult,
But when he finds himself at loss, he reaches in the air
And grasps the word, and uses it, and proudly smooths his hair.

ARMED NEUTRALITY
The most portentious statement made relative to the spectacle of last Monday night, it seems to us, was President Goodnow's quotation of the old proverb "Boys will be boys." All of
Magistrate Hopkins' ominous moralizing upon the fate of Richard
Reese Whittemore, all of the praise that Mayor Howard of the
metropolis of Annapolis received from one of the Baltimore dailies,
all the post mortems by freshmen, sophomores, or others were.
beside the point.
If the police force of Annapolis had been able to realize in
the first place that then- job was to be ready in case of emergency
and not to attempt to interfere with extra-legal goings-on, it is
highly probable that the "riot" that ensued would have been
averted. Baltimore police have, after several years, become accustomed to the annual fracas, and know that the best course of action
is armed neutrality. They stand ready to protect property, but
realize that it would be the height of futility to try to conrol the
situation beyond that.
The Annapolis constabulary, unfortunately, seems to find that
most of its duty leads to the incarceration of inebriated sailors and
berazored negroes, and acts accordingly. The billy, the most effective weapon to employ against these offenders, becomes the staff
of support of Annapolis, and as such keeps the peace by constant
use. We suggest that Mayor Howard ask Commissioner Gaither
to allow him to study police methods in a civilized town.

WHY NOT?
It is indeed encouraging to discover occasionally that a faculty
member considers undergraduates as human beings, and not as
examples of how great a degree of degradation the human race
can reach.
\\Te refer to Dr. Broadus Mitchell's talk at the junior class
banoet early this week. Dr. Mitchell seemed to lament the fact
that in the great majority of cases, relations between instructor and
student end at twenty minutes after the hour. He seems to be one
of the few members of the faculty who are interested in undergraduates and their problems, both scholastically and otherwise.
And what is still more remarkable was the fact that at the banquet
he knew personally most of the men present.
The original idea of this University, it has been often asserted,
was not so much a curriculum of lecture courses as a place where
men could obtain instruction in a given field by work and conversation with the professors in that field. Alas, undergraduates are
not to be so blessed!
The New Plan, of course, fosters just that thing. Eventually,
why not now?

There is a man at Hopkins with a very nervous hand,
Which admits his limitations but which hopes you'll understand.
When his very rambling sentences lead to rather speechless straits
Then he mutters to a lucky pause, and from there, gesticulates.

Hopkins for bigger and better brawls! Hopkins under her
true colors. (Who picked 'em, anyway?) Every sock is a boost
—to Hopkins notoriety! Here's to the blasting of Baltimore,
the annihilation of Annapolis, and eternal bloodiness of class
feuds!
Enthusiasm is rampant on the campus and elsewhere. Everybody who ever had any ideas at all was sure that boys would be
boys, and wasn't greatly surprised when they turned out to be
worse than that. The proof of the theory has brought about citywide recognition, and an interest on the part of the State capital.
\Ve have been in the papers, the jail, and the hospital; we have
discovered that Annapolis, besides having a mayor, is a peaceful
and a moral city; we have destroyed the idea that Hopkins is exclusively an institution of higher education. And ain't we proud!
The public, having found us vastly amusing instead of painfully serious, as college students should be, is feeling exceedingly
indulgent toward us. We are funny ;—therefore we are a fine
lot of exuberant boys having an innocent good-time—at the rate
of three thousand dollars, the papers say.

Dr. Goodnow must have enjoyed the account of the riot.
Imagine him at breakfast Tuesday morning, glimpsing the glaring
head-lines of The Sun over the rim of his coffee-cup. Think how
he must have roared with merriment! How he must have thrilled
to the story of Gordon's sensational flight down the bannisters,
swelled in pride at the oratory Brack employed in his debate
with the old grey mayor, trembled with paternal tenderness upon
reading of the battering of Turnbull's cranium. Can't you just
see the dear old soul wiping the mists of sentiment and tenderness
from his spectacles, and sighing proudly, "Them's my boys"?

And Dr. Ames doubtless became quite apoplectic when they
told him how the church-goers got all wet.
Everyone thinks the entire affair was, in the words of an excited co-ed, "simply gorgeous." It is even reported that the
trustees have been so vividly reminded of their own youthful
pranks that the new plan has been seriously reconsidered. Observing that it would do much toward abolishing all this delightful
smashing of armories, morals, crockery, peace, windows and heads,
and that it would counteract this recent placement of Hopkins on
the collegiate map, these fun-loving, bright-eyed old boys may
have thought better of their dignified proposition.
The whole incident might well be viewed as a moral revolt;
that is wiser than to attribute it to sheer animal spirits. Why not
interpret it thus: the undergraduates, having watched with dismay
the decadence of all branches of sport except lacrosse, having
noticed that the college comic is resting on the laurels of a number produced by outsiders, and that the number of students at
Hopkins is increasing with alarming rapidity, asserted, in this
banquet brawl, their disapproval of the present process of "dignifying" Hopkins. Certainly none of these sober and essentially
peace-loving men desired a fight for the sake of a fight; some of
them may have required stimulant to increase their resolution.
It cannot be believed that anyone enjoyed being bathed at the end
of a fire-hose, or that physical vigor ameliorated the brutal blows
of the over-powering police force. Then there must have been a
purpose—of course there was;—a moral purpose. The whole
Annapolis brawl contains no more than a plea for the continuation
of beloved traditions, of which banquet-rioting is the chief.

that mellow, if slightly coarse flavor
which was once characteristic of
English civilization.
"We have reason to believe," the
article continues, "that not sufficient
:alcohol is consumed in this town.
We know at least one college where
half the members have never known
that pleasant state of inebriation in
Which are hatched the most kindly
plots."

McGill University has organized
a Society for the Suppression of
Vice. The society drew up and sent
to the Student Council recommendations that all future dancing at the
university should be abolished because modern dancing is "lewd, lascivious, indecent and obscene; and
in consequence all dances and all
places where dancing is practiced or
exhibited before the public should
be ruthlessly wiped out." Cigarette
smoking. beer drinking, and "handholding during classes" were also
condemned as being ruinous to the
moral fibre of the student.
. There seems to be a great need
for a Sinclair Lewis or a Henry L.
Mencken at McGill.

Texas University's official Cotillion Club has taken steps to make
its dances a social as well as a financial success. Stags at all dances will
have to pay a "stag tax" to make
Up for their lack of patriotism in
not dragging. This will particularly
hit prominent men on the campus
who are forced by public opinion to
buy tickets and yet take no part in
making the dances a social success.
Such a system we feel-sure would
• not only be practical but would cut
the number of stags at Hopkins
dances considerably.

PORTRAIT OF A PROFESSOR
There is a man at Hopkins, and he is wondrous wise;
He first removes his spectacles and rubs at both his eyes;
And when he finds his eyes are rubbed, and lessened of their pain,
He then picks up his spectacles, and puts them on again.
There is a man at Hopkins who finds it difficult
To discover on his list of.words any one of sense occult,
But when he finds himself at loss, he reaches in the air
And grasps the word, and uses it, and proudly smooths his hair.

ARMED NEUTRALITY
The most portentious statement made relative to the spectacle of last Monday night, it seems to us, was President Goodnow's quotation of the old proverb "Boys will be boys." All of
Magistrate Hopkins' ominous moralizing upon the fate of Richard
Reese Whittemore, all of the praise that Mayor Howard of the
metropolis of Annapolis received from one of the Baltimore dailies,
all the post mortems by freshmen, sophomores, or others were.
beside the point.
If the police force of Annapolis had been able to realize in
the first place that then- job was to be ready in case of emergency
and not to attempt to interfere with extra-legal goings-on, it is
highly probable that the "riot" that ensued would have been
averted. Baltimore police have, after several years, become accustomed to the annual fracas, and know that the best course of action
is armed neutrality. They stand ready to protect property, but
realize that it would be the height of futility to try to conrol the
situation beyond that.
The Annapolis constabulary, unfortunately, seems to find that
most of its duty leads to the incarceration of inebriated sailors and
berazored negroes, and acts accordingly. The billy, the most effective weapon to employ against these offenders, becomes the staff
of support of Annapolis, and as such keeps the peace by constant
use. We suggest that Mayor Howard ask Commissioner Gaither
to allow him to study police methods in a civilized town.

WHY NOT?
It is indeed encouraging to discover occasionally that a faculty
member considers undergraduates as human beings, and not as
examples of how great a degree of degradation the human race
can reach.
\\Te refer to Dr. Broadus Mitchell's talk at the junior class
banoet early this week. Dr. Mitchell seemed to lament the fact
that in the great majority of cases, relations between instructor and
student end at twenty minutes after the hour. He seems to be one
of the few members of the faculty who are interested in undergraduates and their problems, both scholastically and otherwise.
And what is still more remarkable was the fact that at the banquet
he knew personally most of the men present.
The original idea of this University, it has been often asserted,
was not so much a curriculum of lecture courses as a place where
men could obtain instruction in a given field by work and conversation with the professors in that field. Alas, undergraduates are
not to be so blessed!
The New Plan, of course, fosters just that thing. Eventually,
why not now?

There is a man at Hopkins with a very nervous hand,
Which admits his limitations but which hopes you'll understand.
When his very rambling sentences lead to rather speechless straits
Then he mutters to a lucky pause, and from there, gesticulates.

Hopkins for bigger and better brawls! Hopkins under her
true colors. (Who picked 'em, anyway?) Every sock is a boost
—to Hopkins notoriety! Here's to the blasting of Baltimore,
the annihilation of Annapolis, and eternal bloodiness of class
feuds!
Enthusiasm is rampant on the campus and elsewhere. Everybody who ever had any ideas at all was sure that boys would be
boys, and wasn't greatly surprised when they turned out to be
worse than that. The proof of the theory has brought about citywide recognition, and an interest on the part of the State capital.
\Ve have been in the papers, the jail, and the hospital; we have
discovered that Annapolis, besides having a mayor, is a peaceful
and a moral city; we have destroyed the idea that Hopkins is exclusively an institution of higher education. And ain't we proud!
The public, having found us vastly amusing instead of painfully serious, as college students should be, is feeling exceedingly
indulgent toward us. We are funny ;—therefore we are a fine
lot of exuberant boys having an innocent good-time—at the rate
of three thousand dollars, the papers say.

And Dr. Ames doubtless became quite apoplectic when they
told him how the church-goers got all wet.
Everyone thinks the entire affair was, in the words of an excited co-ed, "simply gorgeous." It is even reported that the
trustees have been so vividly reminded of their own youthful
pranks that the new plan has been seriously reconsidered. Observing that it would do much toward abolishing all this delightful
smashing of armories, morals, crockery, peace, windows and heads,
and that it would counteract this recent placement of Hopkins on
the collegiate map, these fun-loving, bright-eyed old boys may
have thought better of their dignified proposition.
The whole incident might well be viewed as a moral revolt;
that is wiser than to attribute it to sheer animal spirits. Why not
interpret it thus: the undergraduates, having watched with dismay
the decadence of all branches of sport except lacrosse, having
noticed that the college comic is resting on the laurels of a number produced by outsiders, and that the number of students at
Hopkins is increasing with alarming rapidity, asserted, in this
banquet brawl, their disapproval of the present process of "dignifying" Hopkins. Certainly none of these sober and essentially
peace-loving men desired a fight for the sake of a fight; some of
them may have required stimulant to increase their resolution.
It cannot be believed that anyone enjoyed being bathed at the end
of a fire-hose, or that physical vigor ameliorated the brutal blows
of the over-powering police force. Then there must have been a
purpose—of course there was;—a moral purpose. The whole
Annapolis brawl contains no more than a plea for the continuation
of beloved traditions, of which banquet-rioting is the chief.
